choices.text: The urease test on a gastric biopsy

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is suspected of having a duodenal ulcer recurrence despite being on omeprazole. Which of the following is the most sensitive test in detecting ongoing infection with Helicobacter pylori?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Serology is simple and convenient and is not affected by the use of PPI or antibiotic use. So in this patient who is already on PPI, this may be the most convenient investigation.

The (13C) urea breath test (Option A) - Highly sensitive but accuracy is reduced by PPI use, which this patient is currently on.

The urease test on a gastric biopsy (Option B) - Also affected by PPI use, which can lead to false negatives.

A gastric fundal biopsy culture (Option C) - Highly specific but less sensitive and technically demanding; not ideal for routine diagnosis.

questions.text: A 46 year old man has had a 5 year history of severe sharp, epigastric pains and diarrhoea. He gets 2-3 episodes of these symptoms a day. His GP has prescribed proton pump inhibitors which has helped partly, but he still complains that the symptoms are severe. Which one of the following might confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Severe epigastric pain with only partial response to PPI indicates a peptic ulcer secondary to Gastrinoma, which is supported by the symptom of diarrhoea.
  • The diagnosis is likely to be Zollinger Ellison syndrome.
  • Gastrin levels are significantly elevated. The secretin testcan help to confirm the diagnosis. There is increased gastrin elevation (greater than 200 pg/mL) in a positive test after secretin is given intravenously .
  • The most common presentation is abdominal pain(gastric acid hypersecretion causes ulceration) followed by diarrhea (due to malabsorption, pancreatic enzyme inactivation by acid)
  • There is an association with the MEN 1 syndrome, so calcium levels should be checked (to screen for a parathyroid adenoma).

The following table shows the circumstances where a gastrin levels should be ordered:

Amylase (Option A) - Used in diagnosing pancreatitis, not useful for evaluating chronic epigastric pain with ulcers and diarrhea.

ERCP (Option B) - Helpful in biliary or pancreatic ductal disorders, not first-line for diagnosing gastrin-secreting tumors.

C-peptide (Option C) - Assesses endogenous insulin production, typically in the evaluation of hypoglycemia or insulinoma, not peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is investigated for weight loss and dyspepsia. Endoscopic examination reveals an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. Biopsy shows the presence of a low-grade mucosa-associated lymphoma and Helicobacter pylori. CT of chest & abdomen shows no metastases. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Helicobacter pylori colonization of the Upper GIT is associated with the following outcomes:

  1. Peptic Ulcer disease. It is more commonly associated with duodenal ulcer than gastric ulcer.
  2. Non-cardio gastric adenocarcinoma
  3. Low-grade gastric B-cell MALT lymphoma

H Pylori provides protection against Reflux esophagitis and its sequelae like Barret esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma.

The diagnosis here is a gastric MALT (Mucosa Associated Lymphoid Tissue) tumour.

  • These are usually marginal zoneB cell lymphomas associated with an excellent prognosis.
  • MALT lymphoma is the third most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • MALT lymphomas are most commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract (stomachis the commonest). But they can be found in any extranodal site.

Low-grade gastric MALT tumours are associated with Helicobacter Pylori infection and respond in over 80% of cases to Helicobacter eradication.

A proportion of patients will not respond to eradication therapy alone and will go on to more conventional anti-lymphoma therapies such as cyclophosphamide, chlorambucil, nucleoside analogues, or radiotherapy.

Radiotherapy (Option A) - Reserved for non-responders or high-grade MALT lymphomas; not first-line for early-stage, H. pylori-associated low-grade disease.

Bilroth's gastrectomy (Option C) - Surgical resection is rarely required in low-grade MALT lymphoma as most cases respond to medical therapy.

Oral chlorambucil (Option D) - Used in lymphoma treatment, but not the initial therapy in H. pylori-positive, localized low-grade MALT lymphoma.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of severe indigestion. 3 years ago, he had a duodenal ulcer seen on endoscopy. Investigations reveal: Fasting gastrin 160 mg/dL. Where is gastrin produced?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastrin is produced by the G cells of gastric antrum. It stimulates parietal cells to produce hydrochloric acid. Its production is stimulated by neural reflex pathways and also by direct effect of digested peptides on the G cells.

Normal fasting gastrin levels are usually < 150mg/dL. Usually all gastrinomas have a fasting gastrin level > 150-200mg/dL

Oesophagus (Option A) - The oesophagus is not involved in hormone production; it serves only as a conduit for food from mouth to stomach.
Colonic mucosa (Option B) - Primarily involved in water absorption and mucous secretion, not hormone secretion like gastrin.
Islet cells (Option D) - Found in the pancreas and involved in insulin/glucagon secretion, unrelated to gastrin production.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman is admitted due to a single episode of haematemesis after taking a tablet of ibuprofen 6 hours previously. On examination, she had a blood pressure of 120/75 mmHg (lying) and 95/60 mmHg (standing). Her haemoglobin concentration is 7.5 g/dL. What is the likely cause of the haemetemesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The likely answer is gastric erosions because the bleeding occurred after only one dose of Ibuprofen. There is no previous history of dyspepsia or upper GI bleeding.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as aspirin, ibuprofen, and naproxen cause gastric erosions via -

  • Can be direct irritantsof gastric mucosa
  • Prostaglandins have a protective role in maintaining mucosal integrity. NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin production.

Because of gravity, the irritants lie on the greater curvature of the stomach, and therefore, gastritis and ulcers are seen distally on or near the greater curvature of the stomach.

Duodenal ulcer (Option A) - Typically presents with chronic, not acute, symptoms; unlikely after a single NSAID dose without prior history of ulcer disease.
Oesophagitis (Option B) - Causes bleeding rarely and usually results from chronic reflux, not acute NSAID use.
Mallory-Weiss Tear (Option C) - Caused by forceful vomiting or retching, which is not reported in this patient's history.

questions.text: Which of the following gut hormones stimulates acid secretion in the stomach?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gastrin is secreted from the G cells of antrum of stomach. when stimulated by parasympathetic nerves and the presence of amino acids in the stomach.
  • It stimulates:
    • Gastric acid productionby parietal cells when stimulated by parasympathetic nerves and the presence of amino acids in the stomach.
    • Gastric motility
    • Growth of gastric mucosa
  • The secretion of gastrin is inhibited by acid in stomach and somatostatin.

Cholecystokinin increases pancreatic secretion and gall bladder contraction. It also relaxes the sphincter of oddi (Option A ruled out)

Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) causes water and electrolyte secretion into intestines. (Option C ruled out)

Secretin increases bicarbonate secretion by pancreas. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A patient presents with haematemesis. An oesophagogastroduodenoscopy detects a bleed in the greater curvature of the stomach. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be the source of the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The greater curvature of the stomach is supplied by -

  • Left gastroepiploic and short gastric arteries -branches of splenic artery. Short gastric arteries also supply the fundus of the stomach.
  • Right gastroepiploic artery -branch of the common hepatic artery

The stomach is exclusively supplied by the branches of the celiac trunk.

The right gastric artery supplies the pylorus and the lesser curvature of the stomach. (Option B ruled out)

The right hepatic artery supplies the right lobe of the liver and part of the caudate lobe. (Option C ruled out)

Cystic artery supplies the gallbladder. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A patient presents with haematemesis. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy detects a bleed in the lesser curvature of the stomach. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be the cause of the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lesser curvature of the stomach is supplied by -

  • Left gastric artery - direct branch of celiac trunk
  • Right gastric artery - branch of common hepatic artery

Left gastro-omental artery (Option A) - Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach, not the lesser curvature.
Cystic artery (Option B) supplies the gallbladder

Right hepatic artery (Option D) - Supplies the liver, not involved in gastric mucosal bleeding.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male laborer presents with a haematemesis. Which of the following features confers the greatest risk of a poor outcome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the options given, history of ischemic heart disease confers the greatest risk of a poorer outcome.

There are a number of available scoring systems which stratify subjects with GI bleed into high and low risk groups.

  • The Rockall scoring systemis based on:
    • Age (the higher the age, the worse the prognosis)
    • Comorbidities (like IHD)
    • Presence of shock
    • Endoscopic abnormalities.
  • The Canadian Consensus Conference Statementutilizes a similar system, incorporating endoscopic factors including:
    • Active bleeding
    • Major stigmata of recent haemorrhage
    • Ulcers greater than 2 cm in diameter
    • The location of ulcers in proximity to large arteries.
  • The Blatchford scoreis based on clinical parameters alone:
    • Elevated blood urea nitrogen
    • Reduced haemoglobin
    • A drop in systolic blood pressure
    • Raised pulse rate
    • The presence of melaena or syncope
    • Evidence of hepatic or cardiac disease.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with haematemesis and melaena. He admits to high alcohol intake. On examination, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute and blood pressure is 92/74 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the epigastrium. What is the most likely underlying cause of the gastrointestinal haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Peptic ulceration is the most common cause of acute upper gastrointestinal (GI) haemorrhage. Epigastric tenderness also points towards peptic ulcer disease. The history of high alcohol intake can be misleading towards varices; however, in this case, the answer is the most common cause of an acute upper GI bleed, which is peptic ulceration.

Gastric antral vascular ectasia (Option A) is a relatively uncommon condition. It typically presents as a cause of iron-deficiency anaemia as a result of chronic GI blood loss. Overt symptoms of upper GI haemorrhage may be precipitated by administration of anti-platelet agents or anti-coagulants. The mean age of diagnosis is around 70, and there is an association with scleroderma.

Portal hypertensive gastropathy (Option D) is a poorly understood complication of portal hypertension (usually as a result of chronic liver disease). There is a typical mosaic or snake skin-like appearance to the gastric mucosa.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man was admitted with pallor, light-headedness, and loss of energy. On the day prior to admission, he had reported loose dark stools. Examination revealed a pulse of 110 per minute and a blood pressure of 106/70 mmHg.Investigations revealed:
Haemoglobin 6.2 g/dl (14-18)MCV 72 fl (80-96)White cell count 11.3 x 10^9/L (4-11)Platelet count 480 x 10^9/L (150-400)
What is the most appropriate next step in his management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has significant microcytic anaemia with a hemoglobin of <7 gm/dl.

He should be resuscitated with blood transfusion and then sent for upper GI endoscopy.

Red cell administration may be a part of volume replacement even without hemorrhage in order to optimize oxygen delivery if hemoglobin content is < 7g

Barium meal (Option A) - Not helpful in an acute GI bleed; it's contraindicated as it delays endoscopy and does not allow therapeutic intervention.

Endoscopy (Option C) - Essential for diagnosis, but only after the patient is stabilized with fluids and/or blood. Immediate endoscopy in unstable patients can worsen outcomes.

Parenteral iron infusion (Option D) - Indicated in chronic iron deficiency anemia, not in acute blood loss scenarios where urgent volume and oxygen-carrying capacity restoration is needed.
